head.title: A Long, Strange Trip for Knoblauch and Co.

hedline.hl1: A Long, Strange Trip for Knoblauch and Co.

abstract.p: New York Yankees player Chuck Knoblauch comments on being involved in controversy in first game of two-stadium doubleheader against New York Mets and hero of second game with three-run home run (S)

block.p: Yankee second baseman Chuck Knoblauch found himself at the center of controversy at the start of the day and a hero by the time the strange Queens-Bronx doubleheader between the Yankees and the Mets concluded last night.

Restlessly making his way through postgame interviews, Knoblauch was focused on making his exit, not on his controversial trip around first base to begin the first game, or his three-run home run to decide the second game, both 4-2 Yankee victories.

Yankee second baseman Chuck Knoblauch found himself at the center of controversy at the start of the day and a hero by the time the strange Queens-Bronx doubleheader between the Yankees and the Mets concluded last night.

Restlessly making his way through postgame interviews, Knoblauch was focused on making his exit, not on his controversial trip around first base to begin the first game, or his three-run home run to decide the second game, both 4-2 Yankee victories.

''It was a very long day,'' he said. ''I'm happy that it's over. The first game ended at about 4:30 and we didn't get here until 6 o'clock. Changing stadiums is kind of crazy when you think about it.''
The Yankees were at least buoyed by sweeping both ends of the home-and-home doubleheader.
''When you're part of something that only happens every hundred years, it's a fun day,'' Yankee reliever Mike Stanton said. ''To tell you the truth, it felt like two days.''
